boat.name: Bryony
boat.full_description:
Bryony is understood to have been built as a yacht for a  Dutchman who brought her to the UK where she has lived ever since.   She  was registered as Heemschipp II in Holland but was registered in Bristol as Quetzal in 1953.   Arthur Buckell found Quetzal at  Elephant Boatyard in a decayed state in 1986 and rebuilt her.   Many  thought that the restoration was impossible, but Arthur proved his work a  success as he plucked another boat off the shore at Yogaff in foul  conditions, winning a well-deserved seamanship prize for his selfless efforts.   He used her as a live aboard, and sailed many miles in her.

In  2002 Arthur felt unable to do her justice anymore, and sold her to Ken Perry who gave her a four year refit before re-launching her in  2007.     Unfortunately, Ken Perry fell ill and by the time the current  owner found her in 2013, she was again in need of a 4-year refit!   As  the new owner lived a long way from the sea in darkest Herefordshire,  Quetzal had a trip on a low-loader and a lift from a very large crane  over the hedge into the owner’s garden. 

There she received a lot of  TLC from the owner, his helpful neighbours and a talented young  boatbuilder from Lowestoft.   She also benefited from the advice of  Arthur, who was still interested to hear about the boat and shared an  album of photos, both of the work he had done and then of the boat under  sail.

During this time she changed name again to Bryony,  after the owner's 19 year-old god-daughter who drowned while surfing in  Thailand on the way back from an oceanography project in Cambodia. She packed so much into her short life that the owner was inspired to  “get on with it” and complete the project. The matter was finally  decided when the owner's gardening book told him that Bryony is of no use  in the garden.

She was re-launched in July 2017 and is now based in Saltash.
